instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not booting
threads.message:
Usb get 19V and goes up to 1.27Amps.

Board getting warm near <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> area. No USB activity, no image external internal, caps button not turning on so my guess board is not entering S0


SMC LID 1.6V


Any common issue with that f----ing T2 boards?

There was liquid damage on sound board, after that customer connected it, touch id button got hot and computer shut down. Nothing mor, board seems be clean enough.



Some rails:


PPBUS 12.94V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> - 5.1V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL>  5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL>  3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>  3.3V



On USB entrance AMPS are going up and down like board is working.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not booting
threads.message: Are you attempting to start machine with Audio board connected? Do you get a fan spin?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not booting
threads.message: I have tried with and without audio board. Same result

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not booting
threads.message: If you talk about J6100, many lines go to T2; it is probably damaged now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not booting
threads.message:
So it must be reprogrammed or board is dead?

P.S. will confirm tomorrow if j6100

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not booting
threads.message:
More likely physically damage.

BTW, the LID signals are pulled-up to 1.8V, so 1.6V looks like good value.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not booting
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not booting
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3900</CHIP> is T2.
You've noted it overheating?

Nothing to do, if T2 is damaged...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not booting
threads.message:
I can confirm that we are talking about J6100. Also can confirm that T2 is getting warm-hot


does warm means is it ok=?



is there any way to retrieve data fromt that mac?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not booting
threads.message:
There is no lifeboat connector.
You cannot directly access SSD untill board boots.
Ask the client if TimeMachine was enabled.

I don't think T2 should get very hot.
In your case is sign of death probably.
Better to compare with working board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not booting
threads.message:
may be getting hot wasnt exact description. It is getting warm. 


What can i check to be sure if it is or not T2?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not booting
threads.message:
Check diode mode readings on the lines between T2 and J6100.
Better to have working board for comparison.
